verses.text: The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son brings sorrow to his mother.
verses.comment: Solomon begins a new collection, emphasizing how wisdom or folly in children deeply affects parents. Traditional wisdom literature often stresses honor and obedience within families. For Christians, honoring father and mother remains essential (see Eph. 6:1-3), echoing the broader spiritual family found in the Church.

verses.text: Treasures gained by wickedness do not benefit, but righteousness rescues from death.
verses.comment: Material wealth amassed through evil offers no ultimate security. True righteousness, which involves both faith and moral living, protects even from spiritual death (compare Rom. 6:23). Note the implied need for ongoing repentance and virtue in the Christian life.

verses.text: The LORD will not let the righteous go hungry, but he thwarts the craving of the wicked.
verses.comment: God's providence favors those who seek Him and live uprightly (Matt. 6:33). This verse encourages trust in the Lord's care, as also reflected in the spiritual discipline of depending on God's provision.

verses.text: Idle hands make one poor, but diligent hands bring wealth.
verses.comment: Industry and diligence are praised as virtues, both for daily living and spiritual growth. Labor offered to God, as seen in Col. 3:23, sanctifies one’s work and strengthens character.

verses.text: He who gathers in summer is prudent; he who sleeps during harvest is a disgrace.
verses.comment: Wise people prepare and act in the appointed time, reflecting foresight and stewardship. Spiritually, this calls for vigilance in responding to divine opportunities.

verses.text: Blessings are upon the head of the righteous, but violence covers the mouth of the wicked.
verses.comment: Figures of speech contrast public honor for the righteous with the destructive speech and reputation of the wicked. Jesus repeats these themes in the beatitudes, indicating both literal and spiritual blessings.

verses.text: The memory of the righteous is blessed, but the name of the wicked will rot.
verses.comment: Righteous living leaves a legacy that endures beyond death, a key concept in Christian tradition regarding sainthood and remembrance. The wicked, by contrast, are forgotten and dishonored.

verses.text: The wise in heart accept commands, but a babbling fool will come to ruin.
verses.comment: Wisdom requires humbly receiving instruction, echoing the call for obedience to spiritual authority. Foolish self-reliance leads to destruction. James 1:19 parallels this, encouraging active listening.

verses.text: Whoever walks in integrity walks securely, but whoever twists his ways will be found out.
verses.comment: Living honestly ensures safety and peace, while secret sin will inevitably be exposed. Christ taught that nothing hidden will remain so forever (Luke 8:17), reminding believers of the need for repentance and confession.

verses.text: Whoever winks the eye causes trouble, but a babbling fool will be ruined.
verses.comment: Winking suggests deceptive intentions. Combined with foolish talk, these habits end in disaster; this theme returns repeatedly in wisdom literature.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
verses.comment: Righteous speech gives life and encouragement—a spiritual analogy for living water, as Jesus described in John 4:14.

verses.text: Hatred stirs up conflict, but love covers all offenses.
verses.comment: Love is powerful in restoring unity and erasing the harm of sins, as reaffirmed in 1 Peter 4:8. This phrase points toward divine mercy and forgiveness, which has both interpersonal and sacramental implications.

verses.text: Wisdom is found on the lips of those who have understanding, but a rod is for the back of one lacking sense.
verses.comment: Instruction and correction are necessary, especially for the foolish. The rod here indicates discipline, a crucial aspect of growth in holiness.

verses.text: Wise people store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool invites ruin.
verses.comment: Wisdom involves patient learning and storing up understanding, in line with spiritual tradition—the fool, on the other hand, persists in self-destructive speech.

verses.text: The wealth of the rich is their fortress, but the poverty of the poor is their ruin.
verses.comment: Earthly wealth provides some security, yet, as throughout Scripture, only spiritual riches satisfy fully. Poverty brings vulnerability; thus, communal charity is urged throughout biblical teaching.

verses.text: The labor of the righteous leads to life, but the gain of the wicked leads to sin.
verses.comment: Faithful work produces true life, echoing the distinction between spiritual fruit and sinful gain (see Rom. 6:23).

verses.text: Whoever heeds instruction is on the path of life, but whoever ignores correction goes astray.
verses.comment: Being open to reproof is integral to growth and salvation. Spiritual discipline is a recurring theme in both Testaments, especially in Hebrews 12:6.

verses.text: Hiding hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.
verses.comment: Obscured malice often comes forth in gossip, which Jesus condemns as a serious sin (Matt. 5:22). True wisdom requires honesty and charity.

verses.text: When words are many, transgression does not lack, but whoever restrains his lips is wise.
verses.comment: Self-control in speech is a hallmark of wisdom (Jas. 1:26). Many words easily lead to sin.

verses.text: The tongue of the righteous is choice silver; the heart of the wicked is of little worth.
verses.comment: Good speech is apt, precious and of great value in God's sight. The inner state of the wicked, in contrast, is poverty-stricken.

verses.text: The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of sense.
verses.comment: Wise speech nourishes others, reminiscent of Jesus’ teaching that spiritual nourishment (the Word) is necessary for life (Matt. 4:4).

verses.text: The blessing of the LORD brings wealth, and he adds no sorrow with it.
verses.comment: True prosperity comes only by God's hand, apart from painful toil. This affirms dependence on divine providence and the peace found therein.

verses.text: Doing wrong is a joy to a fool, but wisdom brings pleasure to a person of understanding.
verses.comment: Spiritual fulfillment comes from seeking wisdom and virtue, not from sinful indulgence. This echoes Psalm 1:2, where delight is found in God's law.

verses.text: What the wicked fears will come upon him, but the desire of the righteous will be granted.
verses.comment: Fear haunts the wicked, but those who live righteously receive God's favor. Spiritual longing is fulfilled by relationship with the Lord.

verses.text: When the whirlwind passes, the wicked are no more, but the righteous stand firm forever.
verses.comment: Temporal disaster wipes away evil, but the righteous remain—like the house built on rock (Matt. 7:24). This points to endurance through faith and upright living.

verses.text: As vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so is the lazy to those who send him.
verses.comment: Laziness brings frustration to others, especially in a community or body relying on each person’s faithful action.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD prolongs life, but the years of the wicked will be cut short.
verses.comment: Reverence for God brings blessings, including length of days (Ps. 91:16), which is often understood both literally and as eternal life through divine fellowship.

verses.text: The hope of the righteous leads to joy, but the expectation of the wicked will perish.
verses.comment: Righteousness is linked to hope, joy, and the life promised in the Lord—a theme fulfilled and deepened in the New Testament.

verses.text: The way of the LORD is strength to the upright, but destruction for evildoers.
verses.comment: God's path gives spiritual strength and safety. Those who reject Him face judgment and ruin; spiritual discernment is essential.

verses.text: The righteous will never be shaken, but the wicked will not inhabit the land.
verses.comment: Eternal security for the righteous recalls Jesus’ promise that the meek will inherit the earth (Matt. 5:5), hinting at the eschatological hope of God’s people.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut off.
verses.comment: True teaching and wisdom are gifts to those living uprightly, a theme seen in the Church’s tradition of protecting sound doctrine from error.

verses.text: The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked knows only what is perverse.
verses.comment: The righteous discern speech that is fitting, implying not only moral correctness but harmony with true worship and community unity (see Heb. 13:15).
